quiz.title: Pre-calculus: Unit 2 Quiz 7
quiz.subtitle: 2.7: Piecewise Defined Functions
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Evaluating and understanding functions with multiple rules

questions.question: Given $f(x) = \begin{cases} 2x + 1 & \text{if } x < 0 \\ x^2 & \text{if } x \ge 0 \end{cases}$, find $f(-3)$.
questions.explanation: Since $-3 < 0$, we use the first rule: $2(-3) + 1 = -6 + 1 = -5$.

questions.question: Using the same function $f(x) = \begin{cases} 2x + 1 & \text{if } x < 0 \\ x^2 & \text{if } x \ge 0 \end{cases}$, find $f(4)$.
questions.explanation: Since $4 \ge 0$, we use the second rule: $4^2 = 16$.

questions.question: On a graph of a piecewise function, what does an open circle represent?
options: The point is not included in the graph (strict inequality).
The point is included in the graph.
questions.explanation: An open circle indicates a boundary that is approached but not reached (associated with $<$ or $>$).

questions.question: Evaluate $g(2)$ for $g(x) = \begin{cases} x - 5 & x \le 2 \\ 10 & x > 2 \end{cases}$
questions.explanation: The 'equal to' part of the constraint is in the first rule ($x \le 2$), so $2 - 5 = -3$.

questions.question: Which parent function can actually be written as a piecewise function: $f(x) = \begin{cases} x & x \ge 0 \\ -x & x < 0 \end{cases}$?
questions.explanation: The absolute value function is defined by its distance from zero, which is $x$ for positive numbers and the negation of $x$ for negative numbers.

questions.question: If a piecewise function has a jump where one piece ends and another begins, the function is said to be:
questions.explanation: A 'break' or 'jump' in the graph means you have to lift your pencil to draw it, indicating a discontinuity.

questions.question: Evaluate $h(0)$ if $h(x) = \begin{cases} x+1 & x < 0 \\ x-1 & x > 0 \end{cases}$
questions.explanation: Zero is not included in either the $x < 0$ or $x > 0$ domain, so the function is undefined at $x = 0$.

questions.question: A cell phone plan costs $\$30$ for up to $2$ GB and $\$10$ for each extra GB. Which represents the cost $C$ for $x$ GB (where $x > 2$)?
questions.explanation: The base cost is $\$30$, and you only pay the $\$10$ rate for the amount over $2$ GB, which is $(x - 2)$.

questions.question: When graphing the piece $y = 3$ for $x > 5$, you should draw:
options: A horizontal ray starting with an open circle at $(5, 3)$.
A horizontal line through the origin.
questions.explanation: Since it is a constant $y=3$ for all $x$ larger than 5, it is a ray extending to the right from an open boundary.

questions.question: Can a piecewise function be even or odd?
options: Yes, if its pieces and domains are symmetric.
No, piecewise functions are always asymmetric.
Only if all pieces are linear.
Only if there is only one piece.
questions.explanation: As long as the overall graph satisfies the symmetry tests, it doesn't matter that it's defined in pieces.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You can navigate multiple rules with ease.
scoreMessages.70: Good work. Pay close attention to which piece contains the 'equal to' sign.
scoreMessages.50: Always check the domain constraint before you plug in your x-value.
scoreMessages.0: Review how to read the 'if' part of a piecewise function.
